thread.title: H.S. basketball: Former Teaneck standout Jim Holsworth dies at 59
thread.title_full: H.S. basketball: Former Teaneck standout Jim Holsworth dies at 59

title: H.S. basketball: Former Teaneck standout Jim Holsworth dies at 59
text:
Print 
Jim Holsworth, who set school scoring records at the Englewood School for Boys in the early 1970s, then transferred and led his hometown Teaneck to its first state sectional title and later coached St. Joseph to the Bergen County Jamboree championship, died Tuesday at age 59. 
Holsworth was cut from the freshman team at Paramus Catholic, ostensibly for being too slow, then led Bergen County in scoring at 35.6 points per game as a junior in 1973 after transferring to the Englewood School for Boys (now Dwight-Englewood), where his achievements were overlooked by many who cited inferior competition. 
So as a senior, Holsworth came home to Teaneck, and even though his scoring average was cut in half, he led the Highwaymen to the 1974 NNJIL title in what was considered one of the top leagues in the state. Later that year, Teaneck lost a classic Jamboree final to Bill Willoughby-led Englewood, then won its first Group 4 sectional title before losing to powerful East Orange in the state semifinals. Holsworth won All-Bergen and All-State recognition at Teaneck. 
He earned a scholarship to St. Peter’s, although injuries cut short his college career. After being an assistant coach at St. Joseph and part of the Green Knights’ 1981 Bergen title team, he was named head coach early in the 1982 season when Dennis Rossi had to step away for personal reasons. Holsworth took a team that returned no starters from the previous season and led it to a 63-57 Jamboree win over Leonia, becoming the first non-public school to repeat as Jamboree champ. 
His son, James Holsworth, the former Passaic Valley coach who recently took an assistant coaching job at Caldwell College, played at Bogota and collegiately at St. Anselm (N.H.). 
Holsworth also is survived by his daughter, Denise. Visiting is 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at Petrik Funeral Home, 140 Palisade Ave., Bogota.
